Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Award: Human Subsistance Practices And Environmental Change - A Botanical Analysis

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Researchers at The Ohio State University, will investigate how incorporating animal domesticates into a foraging base impacts the development of vegetation communities in arid regions. This research project will build on what is understood of agricultural origins by expanding knowledge of food production's implementation in marginal zones beyond sedentary villages. The project data will contribute to a broader effort to understand how ancient human groups created the conditions in which agriculture became the dominant, and eventually exclusive, economic practice across many regions of the world. By setting this particular research in this broader context of human niche construction, the place of pastoralists in the world, both contemporary and past, is reframed. Instead of overexploitation narratives (which characterize much contemporary development literature), pastoralist landscape development and management are viewed as potential innovations and adaptations to new environs which were previously unsuitable to significant population levels. To understand the relationship between food production and local climate on a global scale, pastoralists and their evolutionary landscapes require careful consideration.

Co-PI Abigail Buffington will examine the relationship between the anthropogenic activities of landscape management and the ecology of the broader region of Wadi Sana in the Hadramawt state of southeastern Yemen. This region is today effectively closed to new research projects due to political instability but likely was a significant conduit between regions in prehistory. Domestics from the Levant, South Asia and East Africa eventually became foundational foods in the later agricultural economies of the region. The earliest animal domesticates in Southern Arabia have been recovered from these contexts, as well as evidence of a locally, emergent pastoral economy and very early experiments in vegetation burning and water management. The climatic history of the region provided a beneficial preservation of the sediments in which dating of these discrete phases can be determined. Phytolith assemblages - the microscopic silica deposits that accumulate when plants decay - extracted from these sediments, will be used as signatures of the local plant ecology associated with these niche constructing activities. While this project aims to understand these phytolith groupings as entire entities, there is a possibility that the initial evidence of plant domesticates may be recovered in the course of this study.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Co-PI Abigail Buffington of the Ohio State University studied the vegetation dynamics associated with emergent and continuing pastoral production over five millennia during the Early - Middle Holocene in southeastern Yemen. She systematically sampled 134 sediment contexts for phytoliths - durably preserved plant microfossils of amorphous silica dioxide developed within and between cells of living tissue - assemblages. These sediments included paleosurfaces inter-layerd within silty flood deposits. Geologists have determined that such paleosurfaces represent an ancient episode of landscape stability. In addition, she studied samples from archaeological sites, also inter-layered in silty flood deposits. The suite of samples belong to a sequence of environmental and human events understood in a broad regional and chronological framework. 

The Co-PI compared the samples from sites and those from the environment. This comparison helps her understand long term changes in the environment and in human plant gathering activities and how these affect one another. She designed the project to engage niche construction as an explanation for the emergence and persistence of pastoral economies over time. Niche construction recognizes that human-ecosystem relations have important outcomes for the next generation of people both environmentally and evolutionary. By modeling the dynamics of modern range conditions under pastoral land systems in the arid tropics, the Co-PI developed expected parameters for vegetation. These parameters can be used to interpret patterns of vegetation in the environments surrounding early sites.

The results show that stable land surfaces were associated with an increased presence of arid-tolerant  short grasses. The grasses found on stable land surfaces are best suited to the forage needs of large grazers, like cattle. Human impacts (periodically burning vegetation and channelling water) produced a common vegetation outcome of an short grass dominated community.

Otherwise, the results suggest that human activity was associated with wetland vegetation; humans seem to have enhanced these taxa at their campsites. Archaeological sites also have high counts of the arid-tolerant short grasses. The record suggests that pastoral activity in conjunction with periodic burning increased the productivity of this landscape for animal herding-based economies. The common, but low recovery of palms supports a finding of enhanced moisture during this period in prehistory.

And the productive landscape is evident from the first signs of pastoralists in the archaeological record. Pastoral activity may not have increased the capability of the environment (in the time window this project observed). Pastoral activity probably increased the reliability of environmental resources (grass for grazing) through humans manipulating selected patches. 

Co-PI Abigail Buffington presented research results at five conferences and published results in two peer-reviewed journals. Under the direction of the PI, she developed a laboratory with extraction, counting, documentation and identification capability, a rare resource in the United States. She mentored students and contributed expertise to the development of human and institutional resources in science and online instruction. Finally PI and Co-PI contribute broader impacts as educators and science ambassadors engaging in the Middle East.
